values: Heh.  I actually remembered the password to this thing. Rock on.

Today's scent is Fallen - Cherubic white sandalwood and golden musk with a dark halo of amber, a breath of imperial florals, unbending woods, and the shadow cast by vetiver and violet. I like it all right, but it's faint. On the bright side, the florals aren't overpowering. I'm going to try it again - right now my skin is soaking up everything it can because of the dryness outside, so nothing lasts for long. Also, The Dodo is very much in my swap pile. The only way to describe that one is "If Schizophrenia had a scent" - it's this odd, inconstant and not entirely pleasant mishmash of all sorts of perfume notes, not one of which gets along especially well on my skin. I wish luck to anyone else willing to try it.

Today's BPAL: The name translates to the beautiful woman without mercy, and is the title of an old French court poem that was later revamped by John Keats. A bewitching, seductive scent, rife with mystery and foreboding. 

There are no listed notes for this on the main site, and I'm too lazy to go find it in the forums (www.bpal.org).  It's a dry, dusty-to-powder scent on me, that isn't helped at ALL by the fact the southern half of my state of residence is covered in ash and smells like an autumn bonfire.

Or that it's 90 degrees outside, so now it's a dry, dusty scent mixed with sweat. Yummers. 

x.x I think this one's a swapper - I feel like an old lady's wardrobe wearing it.
Today is one of those days I could really use a few muscle relaxants and a stiff drink or three.

Today's BPAL Scent: Manhattan "A meeting of modern, sleek elegance and rich, passionate history: sheer amber, black leather, white mint, lemon peel, white tea, grapefruit, kush, teakwood and orchid."

Sweet leather - that's all I can describe it as. It's a very sweet, warm leather jacket. VERY nice. I like it a lot. And it's subtle - I won't kill anyone around me from the fumes. This one goes on the 5ml wishlist.

Bewitching, tantalizingand dangerously seductive. A thrilling, exotic blend -- deceptively sweet, but spiked with malice. White ginger, jasmine, and a touch of vanilla.


Just like the description says - it's a bit spicy, but there's a soft sweetness to it. The jasmine in this doesn't become overwhelmingly perfume-y like it does in other blends.  I really rather like it, and I think this may end up on my 5ml wishlist.

Just got this email: "DO NOT TOUCH ANY OASYS NET CHANGES....THIS WILL CAUSE PROBLEMS UNTIL OASYS NET IS BACK UP. YOU CAN NOT EDIT LOCATIONS WITH CHANGES EITHER... THE SYSTEM DIED YESTERDAY. THEY ARE RESTORING TO THE 16TH AS THAT IS A DATE WE HAVE A BACKUP FOR." ... Yesterday, the 17th, I spent 6 HOURS working in the system making changes. Raaaargh!!

Ugh.

So much stuff has just hit my desk I don't even know where to START to make a dent in it. o.O:::  *flail*

*thud*
Queen's "Good Company" really makes me want to learn the ukelele. Really.

Who knew installing another USB-based external drive would fix the hot-swap fuckup on my computer? o.O: I get wireless internet again without playing the unplug-plug-test-unplug-plug game. Fun times. [Still want to convince Mom to install an ethernet port in the office - it' s on just the other side of the same wall! Really!]

You know, if I thought I had something worth writing, I could so very much make my living (or at least supplement my income) as an author. I've cranked out something like 220 single-spaced pages of the same story, and it's not finished yet. [The margins are set to .75" on all sides, to boot - there's technically more per page than average.] Of course, the word 'story' here is something vague and indicates what one could loosely define as an ongoing narrative moreso than a cohesive plotline sort of novel, but I'm having fun writing it, so I suppose that has to count for *something*. (I'll add as an aside that while I understand the need for cohesiveness in writing, I also realize that to some extent, the narrative format is rather like a wordy imitation of real life, and real life doesn't have neat plot twists and a denoument. So... When I write for my own entertainment, I tend to mean it.) [Certain people are allowed to see it, if they REALLY want to, I suppose, but the caveat of "I don't wanna hear about it" stands nonetheless. Like it, hate it, but keep it to yourself. I don't have thick skin on this subject.]

Hey, brimmins:  http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0_15G_tIl38



In other news, I may have gone back up to 173, but my ass looks FANTASTIC in my grey pants today. :D

I don't know who Kate Walsh is, but someone needs to FEED HER, NOW.

*shudder* It's like watching a train wreck, looking at some of these Emmy photos.

One of these days, I'm going to get over this stupid fascination with romance novels. Because the likelihood I'll ever figure out how to experience the sort of thing they describe in purple prose and rosy tones - that likelihood is VERY slim. I guess I just keep hoping that one of these days, I'll have as much in common with the last 200 pages of Rachel Gibson's 'I'm In No Mood For Love' as I do the first hundred. That the story of my life won't keep cycling through the nagging sense of unfulfilled everything like it does now, and that my ugliness as a child won't keep influencing me as an adult. That the one time I accepted a marriage proposal, he turned out to be questionably not-straight. That there is a difference between being touched and being touched, and nerve endings can fire at levels more pleasant and complex than 'ouch' and 'huh?'. That being touched as a woman will someday be not-painful, and god forbid, pleasant. Of course, this hope is also strung along by the unsteady-at-best conviction that I'm not somehow emotionally crippled, either, that I won't always have to delude myself to believe in love or that I might be in-love (because I should be and not because I am), that it IS out there, and that is is attainable. That it's something more intense and interesting than passing fancy or a mild interest. All of that. Maybe there's something wrong with holding myself against the standard of "trashy" novels, but the concept of Happily Ever After is certainly long-standing enough that there must be a grain of truth in it somewhere (let's not delve into the deeper philosophies of the story ending at marriage, for now). I just wish it weren't so damned hard to FIND.

Today's scent is Baobhan Sith - Grapefruit, white tea, apple blossom and ginger. It's a very good warm-weather scent; it isn't too perfume-y or overpowering at all, and remains light and feminine. I'm seriously considering adding this to the 5ml shopping list, but I'm definitely going to order another imp.

Eclipse: All the glory, warmth andmajesty of the sun -- darkened. A delicious blend of bitter almond, vanilla, frankincense and heliotrope, with a drop of cinnamon. This smells... not at all like what it sounds like. And then the cinnamon shows up, faintly. One of the few scents where the cinnamon doesn't become overpowering, however, which is a GOOD thing. It does fade to almost nothing after a while, though. A keeper, I think.

So, the first week of Japanese class is going well. It's 99% review, but it's review I need (like kanji and grammar...). It's damned odd to feel like one of the oldest people in the room, though. Most everyone else in the class is anywhere from 18-20ish. I've found a desk buddy in a very cynical young woman, so it's a mixed blessing - she hates the teacher's "accent" (non-Japanese speaking Japanese) and comments upon it constantly, and is always bored, but at the same time, doesn't know enough of the language to proceed. It's an aggravating mix, no doubt. [We've at least come to the compromise that we'll use the grammar presented to make up absurd sentences of our own.] Humanities is tonight, and while I have misgivings about taking a 3-unit survey class in addition to a 5-unit language course, unless there are numerous essays (unlikely - even Oxy only had 2-3 major essays per class), I should be able to swing it. It means work 5 days a week and class 4 nights a week including Tea, but I think the hardest part is the driving time, not the actual lessons or homework. Even the late hours aren't too bad, if I remember to go to bed shortly after I get home. Sadly, the hardest class so far is the Intro to Insurance class I'm taking *at work* - because it's pretty much reading a chapter at a time in overview, and then listening to a teleconferenced lecture for an hour and a half. No homework to speak of besides the (VERY BORING) reading, and only one exam at the end for a basic designation to add to my email signature if I pass. At least the office covers the cost of the Intro class, because after looking at my credit card statement... OUCH. BIG OUCH. Thunder last night at two am kept me awake far too long, and I'm SLEEPY this morning. Gnar.

Of all the days for my iPod battery to crap out, it had to be today. When the Cube Neighbors From Hell are riled up and noisy. Guh.   (And while the noise is always more than it should be, it's not consistently enough for me to go to the top of the food chain and lodge a complaint yet. I am getting DAMN tired of hearing about his personal life all day long and the assorted racial slurs and condescending assholism he shows to his fellow employees. Ugh.)

At least there's hope - apparently, his internship coincides with the school year. I'm PRAYING he has a full course load and won't come back by the semester start. ;_;

Holeeee crap.


Books cost LESS at private college. o.O: 

Two classes. TWO.

Total for all textbooks? $430.


FIVE classes at a private lib-arts school? $350, give or take. o.O:: 


The FUCK, people??

Dear body,

Stop it. This inconsistent sensitive-not-sensitive tug of war is getting old. Bad enough two of my five sense are constantly being overstimulated to the point of pain, but now simple touch is painful too. What the hell is that? And why the hell can't you be sensitive in fun areas, like erogenous zones? The near-dead nerve endings there are just insult to injury now. 

Gawd. 

----------
In other news, Holy Annoy-a-tron, Batman! Eugie was in the office at 8:45 this morning! I will never get any peace today, dammit. Normally, he shows up at 10am to "work" (you know, that really hard stuff like talking and goofing off and behaving like a middle-schooler around the girls) and takes 3 hour lunches. I guess he got a talking-to or something, because pain in the ass that he is, he's been actually working quietly so far this morning. We'll see what happens, but I'm not going to get my hopes up.

You are The Wheel of Fortune

Good fortune and happiness but sometimes a species of intoxication with success

The Wheel of Fortune is all about big things, luck, change, fortune. Almost always good fortune. You are lucky in all things that you do and happy with the things that come to you. Be careful that success does not go to your head however. Sometimes luck can change.

What Tarot Card are You?
Take the Test to Find Out.

Yeah, that about fits. I'm a lucky, cocky, SOB. ^^;

I am so pathetic. :D :D :D


I just blew $40 on iTunes for dance-trance remixes of 80s one-hit-wonders, movie soundtrack scores, and a few other goodies ('Barbie Girl' for instance). 


Work is going to be FUN today. 


*grooves to the Numa-Numa song, trance-mixed*

Well, if I can't be thin by Saturday morning, at least I'll have clearer skin.  (Though if someone figures out how to drop 25+ pounds in 5 days, let me know, yo! o.o::)

The Queen Helene mint julep mask worked quite nicely, especially with the Aveeno calming lotion afterwards. Straight Vit. E oil on all my old and newer scars seems to be doing at least a little good, not to mention helping the raw spots on my face heal (haaaaaate acne).  And all REALLY affordable, other than the Aveeno (I have yet to find a discount alternative that's available at the corner drugstore).


Tonight, I just may try the aspirin facial. We'll see. (Read about it on
hip_domestics
- take a few of the uncoated, cheapo aspirin, grind 'em up, and add enough water to make a paste, then scrub your face with said paste, smoothing it out and letting it dry. Wash off with warm water.) It's supposed to be good for bumps, lumps, and blackheads, and waaaaaaaaaay cheaper than buying acne products [a buck a bottle of aspirin versus 5 bucks for a scrub, 10 for a cream, etc...] Another trick is plain white toothpaste to dry out trouble spots - dab it on like any spot treatment cream, let dry. (I haven't tried this personally, since I use the stripe pastes, but...) 

At some point I should dye my hair again; it's looking its normal blah ash-grey-brown self again. Bah. The evil part of me that longs for high-maintenance looks REALLY wants to bleach-and-go-copper. Too bad my roots come in charcoal black. Guh. Not worth the $10/box of color every month.

Really. 


Just... the real world keeps sneaking up on me and taking over, that bastard.

I live! 



... And there are more additions to the MLP clan! BWAhahaha~!
